Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Efficient Statistical Inference using Neuroimaging data for Sample Enrichment and Optimizing Power

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hypothesis testing on neuroimaging data traditionally has made use of classical statistical tests (on uni-variate response variables). This makes sub-optimal use of the structure of images, particularly problematic if the two groups being tested have weak differences to begin with. Failure to detect statistically significant differences may imply failure of the experiment itself. Acquiring more images is expensive but also occasionally infeasible. This project develops technologies to address these problems (particularly those dealing with differential analysis of brain images) via the lens of computer vision and machine learning. The algorithmic component of this project is (1) a suite of convex optimization based multi-modal learning schemes to seamlessly leverage a spectrum of brain imaging data, (2) new multi-resolution representations for inference with surface/network based signals (data derived from structural/functional brain images), and (3) using these mechanisms for boosting statistical power even in experiments with small sample sizes.

The project has broad scientific impact. Extending the operating range of statistical image analysis methods for neuroimaging will foster a new inter-disciplinary area at the interface of computer vision, biostatistics, and machine learning, which is highly intellectually stimulating. The research team brings real neuroimaging research data for undergraduate/graduate students to explore and study. The project goals also include training and mentoring of students, increased involvement of under-represented groups, seminars, and an extensive set of outreach activities. In addition, the resultant software tools drive the analysis of neuroscience studies, which has clear broad societal impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits:

This NSF funded project (PI Vikas Singh, UW-Madison) studied a variety of data/image analysis problems motivated by neuroimaging and aging research. The goal was to best utilize data acquired from retrospective studies to identify biomarkers for neurodegeneration and cognitive deficits. Complicating factors include small sized datasets and variations in acquisition protocols at different institutions (e.g., scanners). Highly sensitive statistical and machine learning methods are needed. The PI, in collaboration with his students, designed novel and mathematically rigorous algorithms for a range of such problems. These included harmonic analysis inspired approaches for the analysis of brain connectivity and surface mesh data as well as new statistical models for highly sensitive analysis of longitudinal morphometric changes. New theory was also developed to inform when and if multi-site neuroimaging datasets can be pooled or harmonized and when it would make sense to perform analysis of pooled data. Separately, new algorithms for efficient design of imaging-based clinical trials were developed and methods for analysis of longitudinal/temporal imaging data were derived. The project directly contributed to theory and practical tools at the interface of neuroimaging and vision/machine learning. These results were disseminated in the form of scientific publications at mainstream venues in machine learning, medical image analysis and computer vision, and the team also provided as well-documented and easy to use software toolboxes to the scientific community. Various other research groups have already written follow-up papers building and extending upon the ideas derived as part of this project, which indicates that the results of this research have been appreciated by researchers. The project has also nourished collaborations between the PI's group and numerous scientific/biomedical researchers on the UW-Madison campus and elsewhere.

Broad Impacts:

The project was, by design, interdiscplinary and much of the methodological development was informed by scientific data analysis needs in neuroimaging/aging research. There is a clear and tangible impact that the results of this project have had on neuroimaging. For example, algorithms for brain connectivity analysis, longitudinal morphometric analysis as well as data harmonization have been used, either directly or indirectly, in follow-up papers and have led to subsequent NIH projects with the goal of further developing/validating the ideas.
